<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Sand is a granular material composed of very small, irregularly-shaped mineral particles. A student determines the density of sand by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 571, 135]]<|/det|>
She uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 144, 897, 440]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 452, 420, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[625, 452, 695, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 203, 502]]<|/det|>
**Method 1**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 144, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 515, 180, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 515, 910, 533]]<|/det|>
The student measures the mass of a \(250 \text{cm}^3\) measuring cylinder, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 546, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
She pours sand into the measuring cylinder and measures the mass of the measuring cylinder and sand, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 593, 870, 610]]<|/det|>
Use the values shown in Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2 to calculate the mass \(m\) of the sand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 653, 920, 672]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 686, 181, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 686, 816, 704]]<|/det|>
The student measures the volume \(V_{1}\) of the sand in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 712, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
\[V_{1} = ...............................^{108}....................... \text{cm}^{3}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 747, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value for the density \(\rho_{1}\) of the sand sample. Use the values from **(a)**(i) and the equation \(\rho_{1} = \frac{m}{V_{1}}\). Include a unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 828, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
<form>$\rho_{1} =$ .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 828, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 203, 88]]<|/det|>
**Method 2**

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 97, 760, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 359, 534, 377]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 144, 409]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 390, 180, 409]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 390, 920, 425]]<|/det|>
The student pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of water into the measuring cylinder containing the sample of sand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 421, 920, 456]]<|/det|>
Some of the water soaks into the sand sample and she waits for the water level to become constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 467, 888, 488]]<|/det|>
Record the reading \(V_{2}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 497, 920, 518]]<|/det|>
\[V_{2} = .................................................... \text{cm}^{3} \quad [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 530, 180, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 530, 703, 549]]<|/det|>
Calculate another value for the density \(\rho_{2}\) of the sand sample.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 562, 912, 592]]<|/det|>
Use the values from (a)(i) and (b)(i) and the equation \(\rho_{2} = \frac{m}{(V_{2} - k)}\), where \(k = 100 \text{cm}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 658, 920, 679]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho_{2} =\) .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 97, 581, 344]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 358, 534, 377]]<|/det|>
<mark>[label]Fig. 1.4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 390, 920, 425]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.4, draw an arrow showing the correct line of sight for reading the volume of water in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 406, 920, 425]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 438, 144, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 437, 902, 457]]<|/det|>
Another student wants to determine the density of the particles in a similar sample of sand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 469, 181, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 467, 771, 488]]<|/det|>
Explain why method 1 would not be a suitable method for him to use.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 530, 918, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 560, 181, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 560, 918, 596]]<|/det|>
Explain why method 2 would give a more accurate value for the density of the particles in this sample of sand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 640, 918, 658]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 669, 148, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 669, 920, 702]]<|/det|>
Describe two possible sources of inaccuracy in the measurements taken in method 1 or method 2, even if they are carried out carefully.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 714, 171, 733]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 771, 173, 789]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 823, 918, 842]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 854, 920, 873]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 860, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the cooling of hot water in surroundings with different temperatures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 98, 458, 117]]<|/det|>
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 123, 902, 316]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 327, 533, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 358, 144, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 357, 920, 392]]<|/det|>
The student pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into beaker B and places the thermometer in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 388, 920, 422]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in the appropriate column heading of Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the water, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 428, 574, 540]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 553, 534, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 568, 920, 587]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 599, 146, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 599, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
The student places beaker A inside beaker B as shown in Fig. 2.3 so that the water in beaker B rises between the sides of the two beakers.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 640, 650, 740]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 756, 534, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 787, 920, 820]]<|/det|>
He removes the lid and pours \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A. He replaces the lid and puts the thermometer into the hot water in beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 816, 715, 835]]<|/det|>
He records, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water every 30 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 848, 920, 881]]<|/det|>
Describe **one** precaution that can be taken to ensure that the temperature readings are as accurate as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 925, 920, 943]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 826, 104]]<|/det|> The student repeats the process for water at a higher temperature \(\theta_{2}\) in beaker B. His readings are shown in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 117, 541, 135]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 147, 838, 426]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 438, 920, 472]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion stating in what way the temperature of the water surrounding beaker A affects the rate of cooling of the hot water in beaker A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 660, 489]]<|/det|> Justify your answer by reference to values from the readings. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 592, 920, 611]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 624, 146, 642]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 623, 920, 657]]<|/det|> Calculate the average cooling rate \(R\) for beaker A cooling in **cold** water. Use the readings for beaker A from Table 2.1 and the equation <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 660, 567, 689]]<|/det|> \[R = \frac{\theta_{\mathrm{A}0} - \theta_{\mathrm{A}180}}{T}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 700, 920, 736]]<|/det|> where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{\text{A}0}\) and \(\theta_{\text{A}180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker A at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit for the cooling rate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 791, 920, 812]]<|/det|>
R = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 747, 89]]<|/det|>
Another student repeats this experiment at the same room temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 918, 136]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 170, 166]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 287, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
After 180 s, the student measures the temperature of the water surrounding beaker A in the first experiment and finds that \(\theta_{1} = 49^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 601, 89]]<|/det|>
A student determines the focal length of a converging lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 468, 120]]<|/det|>
She uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 129, 912, 247]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 262, 532, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 293, 144, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 293, 920, 342]]<|/det|>
The student sets the distance \(u\) between the illuminated object and the lens to \(20.0 \text{cm}\). She moves the screen until a sharp image of the illuminated object is seen on the screen. She then measures, and records in Table 3.1, the distance \(v\) between the lens and the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
Describe a technique to obtain an image on the screen that is as sharp as possible in this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 401, 381, 419]]<|/det|>
Include in your description:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 433, 544, 450]]<|/det|>
· where the screen should be placed initially

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 667, 466]]<|/det|>
· how an accurate position for the sharp image is obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 571, 920, 588]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 826, 106]]<|/det|> The student repeats the procedure for \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}, 40.0 \text{cm}, 50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(60.0 \text{cm}\). Her readings are shown in Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 117, 541, 135]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 149, 680, 314]]<|/det|>
\(u/\text {cm}\)\(v/\text {cm}\)\(\frac {u}{v}\)
20.060.0
30.027.31.10
40.025.81.55
50.021.42.34
60.020.03.00
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 325, 769, 348]]<|/det|> For distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\), calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the value of \(\frac{u}{V}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 329, 920, 346]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 358, 144, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 356, 836, 380]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(u / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(\frac{u}{V}\) (x-axis). Start your graph at the origin (0,0). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 389, 332, 408]]<|/det|> Draw the best-fit line. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 415, 824, 875]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 898, 920, 917]]<|/det|> [4]

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 106, 920, 128]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 510, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the brightness of a lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the intensity (brightness) of the light produced by the lamp is affected by the current in the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 398, 166]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 366, 198]]<|/det|>
· a lamp and power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 667, 213]]<|/det|>
· a light meter which measures the intensity of light arriving at it

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 211, 260, 227]]<|/det|>
· an ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 310, 244]]<|/det|>
· a variable resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 324, 276]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 136, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 288, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 4.1 to show the variable resistor connected to control the current in the lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 138, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 320, 504, 338]]<|/det|>
state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 490, 354]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the experiment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
· draw a table with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 603, 400]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 437, 875, 580]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 604, 532, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>
